197: 
198: $$

hints.section: ## 4. N-Uniform Poincaré Inequality for Geometric Gas
hints.raw_directive:
191: ### 4.1. Conditional Poincaré for Multivariate Gaussian
192: 
193: :::{prf:theorem} N-Uniform Poincaré Inequality (Velocity Marginal, Geometric Gas)
194: :label: thm-poincare-geometric
195: 
196: The marginal velocity distribution $\pi_N^{\text{vel}}(\mathbf{v})$ of the Geometric Gas QSD satisfies:
197: 
198: $$
199: \text{Var}_{\pi_N^{\text{vel}}}(g) \leq C_P(\rho) \sum_{i=1}^N \int |\nabla_{v_i} g|^2 d\pi_N^{\text{vel}}
200: $$
201: 
202: where:
203: 
204: $$
205: C_P(\rho) = \frac{c_{\max}^2(\rho)}{2\gamma}
206: $$
207:

hints.label: proof-thm-poincare-geometric
hints.content:
211: :::{prf:proof}
212: :label: proof-thm-poincare-geometric
213: **Step 1 (Conditional Poincaré for multivariate Gaussian):**
214: For any fixed $\mathbf{x}$, the conditional distribution $\pi_N(\mathbf{v}|\mathbf{x}) = \mathcal{N}(0, \Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}(\mathbf{x}))$ is a multivariate Gaussian. By Bakry-Émery (1985), it satisfies a Poincaré inequality:
215: 
216: $$
217: \text{Var}_{\pi_N(\mathbf{v}|\mathbf{x})}(g) \leq \lambda_{\max}(\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}(\mathbf{x})) \int |\nabla_{\mathbf{v}} g|^2 d\pi_N(\mathbf{v}|\mathbf{x})
218: $$
219: 
220: where $\nabla_{\mathbf{v}} = (\nabla_{v_1}, \ldots, \nabla_{v_N})$ and $|\nabla_{\mathbf{v}} g|^2 = \sum_{i=1}^N |\nabla_{v_i} g|^2$.
221: 
222: **Step 2 (Apply N-uniform bound):**
223: By Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-eigenvalue-bound-geometric`, $\lambda_{\max}(\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}(\mathbf{x})) \leq c_{\max}^2(\rho)/(2\gamma)$ uniformly in $\mathbf{x}$, $N$, and $\nu$. Therefore:
224: 
225: $$
226: \text{Var}_{\pi_N(\mathbf{v}|\mathbf{x})}(g) \leq \frac{c_{\max}^2(\rho)}{2\gamma} \sum_{i=1}^N \int |\nabla_{v_i} g|^2 d\pi_N(\mathbf{v}|\mathbf{x})
227: $$
228: 
229: **Step 3 (Extend to marginal via Holley-Stroock):**
230: The marginal velocity distribution $\pi_N^{\text{vel}}(\mathbf{v}) = \int \pi_N(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{v}) d\mathbf{x}$ is a mixture of these conditional Gaussians (mixing over $\mathbf{x}$). By Holley-Stroock (1987), the Poincaré constant for a mixture is bounded by the supremum of the Poincaré constants of the components:
231: 
232: $$
233: C_P(\pi_N^{\text{vel}}) \leq \sup_{\mathbf{x}} C_P(\pi_N(\mathbf{v}|\mathbf{x})) = \sup_{\mathbf{x}} \lambda_{\max}(\Sigma_{\mathbf{v}}(\mathbf{x})) \leq \frac{c_{\max}^2(\rho)}{2\gamma}
234: $$
235: 
236: Therefore, for functions of velocity only:
237: 
238: $$
239: \text{Var}_{\pi_N^{\text{vel}}}(g) \leq \frac{c_{\max}^2(\rho)}{2\gamma} \sum_{i=1}^N \int |\nabla_{v_i} g|^2 d\pi_N^{\text{vel}}
240: $$
